prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We set CI 1-0 with a resolution of 0.6 km/s, which will be futher smoothed to about 10-20 km/s resolution. We set other basebands to be the continuum mode to lower the data rate.

For band 8, we ask for the most compact array configuration (C36-1) which offers an angular resolution of 0.7$''$, and good phase stability across the array requisite for high fidelity imaging at these high frequencies. This beam size corresponds to $\sim$ 250 pc, given the averaged distance of $\sim$ 80 Mpc. The largest angular scale per channel is estimated to be smaller than 4".

Using APEX, we detected CI in NGC2623 with a velocity-integrated line flux of 10 Jy\kms, and a line width of 140 kms (FWHM). Assuming the emission at each velocity detected with APEX evenly distributes in 30 beams, the expected flux in each beam will be 100 mJy for the velocity component at the peak of the spectrum, while it will be about 30 mJy in each beam for the entire velocity range. For detailed study of this line, we ask for a rms noise level of $\sim$3 mJy/beam for a $\Delta$V$_{\rm chan}$ = 15 \kms, which will give the signal to noise ratio of 10 for most of the velocity range of the emission. This noise level corresponds to $\sim 2.1 \times 10^6 M_\odot$ \htwo\, mass (within a 250 pc$^2$ beamsize), a typical mass of Galactic giant molecular cloud association.

USBs are set for CO 1-0 and CN 1-0. LSBs covers a few interesting dense gas lines: HC3N 11-10, HC5N 38-37, 39-38, H2CS, CH3CCH, etc. which have been detected with IRAM 30m in a few nearby LIRGs. (Aladro et al. 2005)

For band 3, we ask for C36-4 configuration to match with the angular resolution of \ci, 0.7$''$. This beam size corresponds to $\sim$ 250 pc, given the averaged distance of $\sim$ 80 Mpc. The largest angular scale per channel is estimated to be smaller than 4".

We found CO 1-0 NGC2623 has a velocity-integrated line flux of 89 Jy km/s, and a line width of 140 kms (FWHM). Assuming the emission at each channel evenly distributes in 30 beams, the expected flux in each beam will be 30 mJy for the velocity component at the peak of the spectrum, while it will be about 10 mJy in each beam for the entire velocity range. We ask for a rms noise level of 3 mJy/beam for a V_channel = 15 km/s. This corresponds to ~ 2.4 x 10^6 Msun molecular mass, the same depth as CI does.

The good integration time on the applied strongly lensed galaxies may detect other lines as dense gas tracers, which will be very valuable for bonus studies as astro chemistry, or properties on dense gas excitation.
We set CI 1-0 with a resolution of 0.6 km/s, which will be futher smoothed to about 10-20 km/s resolution. We set other basebands to be the continuum mode to lower the data rate.

For band 8, we ask for the most compact array configuration (C36-1) which offers an angular resolution of 0.7$''$, and good phase stability across the array requisite for high fidelity imaging at these high frequencies. This beam size corresponds to $\sim$ 250 pc, given the averaged distance of $\sim$ 80 Mpc. The largest angular scale per channel is estimated to be smaller than 4".

Using APEX, we detected CI in IRAS18293 with a velocity-integrated line flux of 30 Jy\kms, and a line width of 300 kms (FWHM). Assuming the emission at each velocity detected with APEX evenly distributes in 30 beams, the expected flux in each beam will be 230 mJy for the velocity component at the peak of the spectrum, while it will be about 70 mJy in each beam for the entire velocity range. For detailed study of this line, we ask for a rms noise level of $\sim$3 mJy/beam for a $\Delta$V$_{\rm chan}$ = 15 \kms, which will give the signal to noise ratio of ~20 for most of the velocity range of the emission. This noise level corresponds to $\sim 2.1 \times 10^6 M_\odot$ \htwo\, mass (within a 250 pc$^2$ beamsize), a typical mass of Galactic giant molecular cloud association.

USBs are set for CO 1-0 and CN 1-0. LSBs covers a few interesting dense gas lines: HC3N 11-10, HC5N 38-37, 39-38, H2CS, CH3CCH, etc. which have been detected with IRAM 30m in a few nearby LIRGs. (Aladro et al. 2005)

For band 3, we ask for C36-4 configuration to match with the angular resolution of \ci, 0.7$''$. This beam size corresponds to $\sim$ 250 pc, given the averaged distance of 80 Mpc. The largest angular scale per channel is estimated to be smaller than 6", estimated from 1.4 GHz radio images (Condon et al. 1990).

We found CO 1-0 in IRAS18293 has a velocity-integrated line flux of 500 Jy km/s, and a line width of 300 kms (FWHM). Assuming the emission at each channel evenly distributes in 30 beams, the expected flux in each beam will be 150 mJy for the velocity component at the peak of the spectrum, while it will be about 50 mJy in each beam for the entire velocity range. We ask for a rms noise level of 3 mJy/beam for a V_channel = 15 km/s. This corresponds to ~ 2.4 x 10^6 Msun molecular mass, the same depth as CI does.

The good integration time on the applied strongly lensed galaxies may detect other lines as dense gas tracers, which will be very valuable for bonus studies as astro chemistry, or properties on dense gas excitation.
We set CI 1-0 with a resolution of 0.6 km/s, which will be futher smoothed to about 10-20 km/s resolution. We set other basebands to be the continuum mode to lower the data rate.

For band 8, we ask for the most compact array configuration (C36-1) which offers an angular resolution of 0.7$''$, and good phase stability across the array requisite for high fidelity imaging at these high frequencies. This beam size corresponds to $\sim$ 250 pc, given the averaged distance of $\sim$ 80 Mpc. The largest angular scale per channel is estimated to be smaller than 4".

Using APEX, we detected CI in NGC5104 with a velocity-integrated line flux of 10 Jy\kms, and a line width of 300 kms (FWHM). Assuming the emission at each velocity detected with APEX evenly distributes in 30 beams, the expected flux in each beam will be 100 mJy for the velocity component at the peak of the spectrum, while it will be about 30 mJy in each beam for the entire velocity range. For detailed study of this line, we ask for a rms noise level of $\sim$3 mJy/beam for a $\Delta$V$_{\rm chan}$ = 15 \kms, which will give the signal to noise ratio of ~10 for most of the velocity range of the emission. This noise level corresponds to $\sim 2.1 \times 10^6 M_\odot$ \htwo\, mass (within a 250 pc$^2$ beamsize), a typical mass of Galactic giant molecular cloud association.

USBs are set for CO 1-0 and CN 1-0. LSBs covers a few interesting dense gas lines: HC3N 11-10, HC5N 38-37, 39-38, H2CS, CH3CCH, etc. which have been detected with IRAM 30m in a few nearby LIRGs. (Aladro et al. 2005)

For band 3, we ask for C36-4 configuration to match with the angular resolution of \ci, 0.7$''$. This beam size corresponds to $\sim$ 250 pc, given the averaged distance of 80 Mpc. The largest angular scale per channel is estimated to be smaller than 4", from 1.4G Hz radio images (Condon et al. 1990).

We found CO 1-0 in NGC 5104 has a velocity-integrated line flux of 150 Jy km/s, and a line width of 300 kms (FWHM). Assuming the emission at each channel evenly distributes in 30 beams, the expected flux in each beam will be 35 mJy for the velocity component at the peak of the spectrum, while it will be about 13 mJy in each beam for the entire velocity range. We ask for a rms noise level of 3 mJy/beam for a V_channel = 15 km/s. This corresponds to ~ 2.4 x 10^6 Msun molecular mass, the same depth as CI does.

The good integration time on the applied strongly lensed galaxies may detect other lines as dense gas tracers, which will be very valuable for bonus studies as astro chemistry, or properties on dense gas excitation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The fine structure lines of atomic carbon, [CI], stand out as the best alternative tracer of molecular gas in galaxies other than CO, because they have suitable range of critical densities, excitation temperatures, small optical depths, while the CI abundance is highly increased under the influence of strong cosmic rays (CR) due to the destruction of CO. However, they must be benchmarked locally against the widely used low-J CO transitions as global molecular gas tracers. We propose to image [CI] 1-0 and CO J=1-0 (with CN N=1--0 as bonus transitions) in three local luminous infrared galaxies, drawn from a population of dusty and vigorously star-forming galaxies, as good analogues of high-z sub-mm galaxies.This allows a sensitive assessment of the relative H2-tracing capabilities of [CI] 1-0, CO 1-0, and submm dust on 250 pc scales, and a search for the predicted CR-induced CO-destruction. The proposed study will open a new window to better determine molecular gas mass in galaxies, near and far.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, Edinburgh , University of

Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
